0.body: I'd actually never dare to contact theod who deleted my comment. It would equal instant ban.

0.author: tisnik
0.body:
pi is defined as the ratio of length of circle and its diameter.

l = 2 \* pi \* r = pi \* d    ->    pi = l/d.

You'd have to redefine what a circle is. Right now it's a set of all points that have same distance from certain point - mathematically (x-m)\^2 + (y-n)\^2 = r\^2  where \[m,n\] is the point and r is the distance.

And that's tough.

But theoretically possible, if you redefine everything you need.

0.author: mage36
0.body: I was referring to that rather absurd "proof" that PI = 4 as shown [this picture.](http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-077tVMIvmlo/T8WXPvWEM-I/AAAAAAAAEmM/GvtoToIOW4g/s1600/pi-4.png) You're right, it redefines what a circle is, but only barely.

1.author: Marksideofthedoon
1.body:
"Many people argue that's a good thing. In a 2002 survey conducted for PBS/Frontline by the Kinsey Institute for Research in Sex, Gender and Reproduction at Indiana University, ***86 percent*** of respondents said porn can educate people, and ***72 percent*** said it provides a ***harmless outlet*** for fantasies. ***Among those who reported using pornography, 80 percent said they felt "fine" about it.***  
  
***"There are a lot of people out there using a lot of porn who have no problems with it whatsoever,"*** says Erick Janssen, PhD, a senior scientist at the Kinsey Institute. "So when does it become an addiction?"  


Can't find a single line in this article that states anything about "Lizard brains" or "adaptations to X stimuli".   
So it says exactly what every rational person understands : Abuse of ANYTHING can be bad. Moderation of MOST things is healthy and does NOT cause issues. Did you even read the article?  


It says 9 percent of people surveyed found it difficult to stop. Unfortunately, the article fails to express the amount of people it surveyed so that number is useless for drawing any conclusions.  


YOU claim (and I quote) : ***Our bodies have adapted for real situations, and since porn basically provides all of the stimulation without any of the need for development, it essentially fucks up your lizard brain into thinking it has hit the procreational jackpot.***  


None of which is mentioned in this article. I'm open to ready ANY source that backs up your claim that includes any of the points you originally stated. There are many points in the article that state that viewing pornography under certain conditions (i.e Couples watching it together) in fact *increase* sexual satisfaction with said partner. It even goes so far to say that results are *inconclusive* because it faces the chicken and egg paradox. Do partners resort to porn because they feel unhappy in the relationship or are they unhappy *because* they watch porn?  


I genuinely don't think you read the article.

1.author: That_NotME_Guy
1.body:
My god man. I did read the article. And I'm pretty sure that we both know that when people say porn is bad, it comes with the unspoken "for guys". It guys who usually have issues with it.

Guys that watched porn felt depressed, with low self esteem and low sex drive. The article mentiones that the porn they watch is usually devoid of context. This is what I'm talking about. The brain gets its satisfaction (seeing sexual acts) without the development of how it got to that situation. Porn is overall, bad (for dudes, I guess)

Think about it this way: porn gives you the benefit of sexual gratification, easily. This, however, isn't how we would do things in nature. To get sexual gratification, one would have to have sex. But to have sex, you would have needed to develop your social and interpersonal skills and have some sort of an elevated position in your local hierarchy. In this way, getting sex is an incentive. With porn, that's gone.

6.author: rookieoo
6.body:
Ok, now I'll argue a bit. Your first reply to me was false. I gave three reasons in my initial comment: 1. We're good at math 2. We've been doing it for generations. 3. Fractions are fun. I never claimed these were arguments of superiority. You're making your own goal post and then pestering me as to why I'm not aiming for it. 

You're trying to control the terms used in this conversation (argument vs reason) instead of giving reasons why it bothers you that America doesn't use the metric system. What I think is interesting is that I already said that the metric system has more advantages, presumably something you think. Yet, you still had a bone to pick? Because I still use inches and feet to build barns? That's literally what I do. I can build a 90'×60' pole barn with a tongue and groove interior finish all with feet and inches. I don't need a single argument as to why I use it besides that it works and it's what I choose. 

Have you been to the US? If not, I recommend a trip!
